perturbation.original_text: Section 4.3. Termination for Breach. If either party materially breaches one or more of its obligations hereunder, the other party may terminate this Agreement, effective upon written notice, if the breaching party does not cure such breach within 15 days after written notice thereof (or any mutually agreed extension). Licensor may terminate this Agreement immediately, effective upon written notice, if (i) Licensee attempts to violate Section 8 or (ii) a sublicensee materially breaches its sublicense in a manner that harms the Brand, and (a) such sublicensee does not cure the same within 15 days after notice from Licensor or Licensee or (b) Licensee does not terminate such sublicense within 15 days after notice from Licensor.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 4.3. Termination for Breach. If either party materially breaches one or more of its obligations hereunder, the other party may terminate this Agreement, effective upon written notice, if the breaching party does not cure such breach within 5 days after written notice thereof (or any mutually agreed extension). Licensor may terminate this Agreement immediately, effective upon written notice, if (i) Licensee attempts to violate Section 8 or (ii) a sublicensee materially breaches its sublicense in a manner that harms the Brand, and (a) such sublicensee does not cure the same within 5 days after notice from Licensor or Licensee or (b) Licensee does not terminate such sublicense within 5 days after notice from Licensor.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 15-day cure period for a material breach of contract. Shortening this cure period to 5 days could be deemed unreasonable in some jurisdictions, particularly for complex breaches. Many states favor providing a reasonable opportunity to cure a breach, and 5 days may be insufficient, leading to potential legal challenges to the termination. Breaching the covenant of good faith and fair dealing by providing such a short time frame may also cause legal issues.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract Laws (general contract law principles of reasonable cure periods) and Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing.

perturbation.original_text: Section 9.1. Notice. Any notices herein shall be deemed to have been duly given if (i) delivered or delivered by facsimile, when received, (ii) sent by U.S. Express Mail or recognized overnight courier, on the following business day or (iii) delivered by electronic mail, when received:
perturbation.changed_text: Section 9.1. Notice. Any notices herein shall be deemed to have been duly given if (i) delivered or delivered by facsimile, when received, (ii) sent by U.S. Express Mail or recognized overnight courier, on the fifth business day or (iii) delivered by electronic mail, only when acknowledged by the recipient within 12 hours of sending:
perturbation.explanation: The modification alters the notice provisions. Changing the receipt of notices via courier to the 'fifth business day' creates potential delays in important communications, which is generally inappropriate in legal settings. Moreover, providing emails shall be delivered when acknowledged within 12 hours of sending might be considered unreasonable and contradict common business practices in certain contexts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Notice Requirements and Reasonableness Standards.

perturbation.original_text: Section 4.2. Termination for Convenience. Licensor reserves the right to terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice for any reason, including if the usage of the Brand is not in compliance with the standards and policies.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 4.2. Termination for Convenience. Licensor reserves the right to terminate this Agreement without any prior written notice for any reason, including if the usage of the Brand is not in compliance with the standards and policies.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the requirement of written notice for termination for convenience may violate the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, depending on the jurisdiction and the specific circumstances. Many jurisdictions require some form of reasonable notice even in at-will contractual relationships to avoid unfair surprise or undue hardship. Lack of notice could lead to claims of breach of implied contractual duties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (implied in most contracts) and general contract law principles regarding reasonable notice.
